Archaeology Notes.

Prof. David M. Robinson delivered a series of three lectures on
December 5 and 6 at the Alleghany
College, Meadeville, Pa., on the following subjects:"Caricature, Asia
Minor, and War Memorials."
On December 10, at 4.30 P. M.,
Prof. Joseph Clark Hoppin, a wellknown author of books on Greek
vases, will give an illustrated lecture in the Civil Engineering Hall
on "Greek Vases." On December 19,
at 4.30 P. M., Prof. Edgar Hewett,
director of the American School
of Research in Santa Fe, will also
present an illustrated lecture in
the Civil Engineering Hall on"Our
Aesthetic Heritage." Both of these
lectures will be given under the
auspices of the Baltimore Archaeological Society,..and the students
of Johns Hopkins University are
invited to attend them.

Swimming Team Shaping Up.

The Johns Hopkins swimming
team in under way now and its
members are working earnestly to
perfect themselves for the future
meets. Twenty.men have reported
for practice, six of whom were on
last'year's squad. These men—
Captain Hall, Manager Gould,
Reins, Slingluff, D. Rowland and
H.Rowland are being coached especially in the 220-yard swim. D.
Rowland seeths to be the star in
the practice dashes and Slingluff
leads them all in fancy diving.

CHESS CLUB HOLDS TOURNAMENT; SAIONTZ IS LEADING

The tournament being staged by
members of the Chess Club is progressing slowly but surely. In the
few games float have been played
R. L. Saiontz is leading, having
won all his matches so far. At the
end of the tournament, a chess
team (or possibly several teams)
will be formed of the best players.
Those competing in the tournament are: Kurrelmeyer, Shaw,
R. L. Saiontz, Douglas, Essers,
Parker, Feder, Yursick, Bowen,
Cohen, C. B. Saiontz, Hettleman,
Zubin, Feldman, Shortess, Hoen,
Mallalien, Taylor, Falkoff, M. Levin, P. Levin, Schiavo, Latane, Kabinofsky, Cromwell, B. S. Levin
and Rosenthal.
Mr. Spargo to Address Social
Science Club.

Mr. John Spargo, a prominent
American Socialist, is to address
the January -meeting of the Hopkins Social Science Club. Mr.
Spargo was prominent as a leader
in the American Socialist Party
until that party came out against
the war. Mr. Spargo and others
that supported the war resigned.
from the party after submitting a
minority report. In his book on
"Bolshevism," Mr. Spargo attacks
it as a form of autocracy and not
socialism. The subject and exact
date of Mr. Spargo's lecture will
be announced later. The next
meeting of the club will be held at
4 o'clock on Friday, December 19,
and will be addressed by ex-Judge
Alfred S. Niles.

the new men. Shas and Campbell
are excellent divers, as well as

hard for the dashes.
The schedule of practices has
been changed somewhat. The team
now meets at the Baltimore Athletic Club on Wednesday at 4.30
P. M., Thursday at 8.45 P. M., and
Friday at 4.30 P. M. The first
meet will be with the University
of Pennsylvania on Friday night,
December 19, at 8.30 o'clock. This
meet will be held at the Baltimore
Athletic Club and will be governed
by the inter-collegiate swimming
rules. The following events have
been arranged: 220-yard swim, relay (160 yards), 50-yard dash,
plunge, and fancy diving, and will
wind up with an exhibition water
polo game.

Unless college professors receive
increased salaries soon "the last
college professor will die of malnutrition in'November, 1926," predicts Eliot Wadsworth, chairman
of the Harvard Endowment Fund.
He continues:"A stuffed specimen
of the collegii professorianus will
then doubtless be placed along
with the dodo, the five-cent fare
and the gin rickey in the Smithsonian Intitution."
In Wisconsin nine colleges have
become associated to appeal to the
state for $5,000,000 during the
week of November 12-19 to solve
this problem of inadequate salaries for teachers and to meet other
immediate, pressing needs.

Too much Turkish
or

Just enough Turkish?
N one way, at least, smoking is
exactly like eating.
The more rich and delicious a
certain food is, the more care people
take to avoid eating too much of
it— for instance, plum pudding or
candy.

I

Perhaps this is the main reason
why so many smokers of straight
Turkish cigarettes keep switching
to Fatimas.

Less worry about
''too many"

Th3 Sam:" rule applies to smoking.
Cigar smokers, for example, are
today more careful to avoid too
many rich, heavy Havanas. (In fact,
mor3 and more cigar smokers now
smoke cigarettes too, to help cut
down the number of cigars.)
In th3 same way,cigarette smokers
are learning that Turkish tobacco,
delicious as it is, is so over-rich or
heavy, that a man can easily smoke
too much of it.
But they are learning also that,
instead of cutting down the number
of cigarettes per day, they can cut
down on the propoKion of Turkish
in each cigaret:c.

How to reduce on
Turkish
THEYcan dothis byswitching from
1- straight Turkish to part Turkish,
or "Turkish blend," cigarettes.
The first Turkish blend cigarette
ever made —and the one which has
always held first-rank importance—
is Fatima.
Fatima contains more Turkish
than does any other Turkish blend
cigarette.

ANOTHER reason undoubtedly is
11-• the fact that Fatimas treat
smokers so kindly. The Turkish is
so perfectly "balanced" by the other
tobaccos in the blend that Fatima
smokers never have any worry about
smoking "too many."
*

*

*

AT any rate, whatever the reason
may be,Fatima keeps on attracting more and more cf those smokers
who, if they preferred the fancy,
expensive, straight Turkish cigarettes, could easily afford them.
This is shown, of course, by
Fatima's record in having won the
top notch in sales at so many of the
fashionable clubs and hotels and
other prominent places all over the
country.

How much
is "just enough"?
not Fatima's record scem to
DOES
prove that this is the one cigarette containing just enough Turkish?
Not too much nor too little Turkish,
but just enough. Make a test for
yourself.

Perhaps to the students whose
homes are in Baltimore this lack
of gymnasium work at the University can be easily made up for by
exercise taken in their own yards
or houses. But we luckless inhabitants of nearby boardinghouses have no such opportunity.
We are, indeed, at a double disadvantage, because not only do
we lack facilities for physical
training, but, in addition, our systems must also suffer the continual abuse of boarding-house
menus, all of wliich are apparently planned to please the palate—
not the digestive apparatus.
The class which I hope may be
estdblished need not, I should
think, meet more than two days a
week. In my opinion, membership
in this class should be obligatory
among the freshmen and sophomores, for the military training
course at Hopkins is by no means
a satisfactory substitute for physical training. Many other universities require two years of both
military and gymnasium work,
hence it would not be imposing a
severe hardship on students to require them to take physical training in addition to the R. O. T. C.
course. Members of athletic teams,
of course, would be excused from
this proposed class.
The matter 'of good health as
fostered by proper bodily exercise
is clearly of great importance to
students. Real.work can be done
consistently only by students
whose systems are toughened by
regular bodily exercise. Hopkins
men should .not be characterized
by sallow complexious and flabby
muscles. '
N. M.
Attacks "Innocent Sufferer."
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—In your issue of last week
a letter appeared in the Mail Bag
in reference to the R. 0. T. C.
shoes and signed "Innocent Sufferer." "Innocent Sufferer" inferred that he could not study,
that his brain refused to work
whenever an R. 0. T. C. man shuffled his feet. It seems to me that
if the poor sufferer's brain had
only been of a kind that.produces
thought, he might have benefited
himself by observing the army
shoe. If he himself wore shoes of
army type his pedal extremities
would profit immensely in spite
of the noise.
Moreover, if this same "Innocent -Sufferer" had any college
spirit at all, even in most rudimentary form, it seems to me he
would either now be a member of
the organization which he so sarcastically criticizes or he would
keep his ridicule within his own
misguided mind. If such creatures
cannot boost a college activity, at
least they can and should refrain
from knocking it.
AN ANTI-"INNOCENT SUFFERER."

Archaeology Notes.

Prof. David M. Robinson delivered a series of three lectures on
December 5 and 6 at the Alleghany
College, Meadeville, Pa., on the following subjects:"Caricature, Asia
Minor, and War Memorials."
On December 10, at 4.30 P. M.,
Prof. Joseph Clark Hoppin, a wellknown author of books on Greek
vases, will give an illustrated lecture in the Civil Engineering Hall
on "Greek Vases." On December 19,
at 4.30 P. M., Prof. Edgar Hewett,
director of the American School
of Research in Santa Fe, will also
present an illustrated lecture in
the Civil Engineering Hall on"Our
Aesthetic Heritage." Both of these
lectures will be given under the
auspices of the Baltimore Archaeological Society,..and the students
of Johns Hopkins University are
invited to attend them.

The Johns Hopkins swimming
team in under way now and its
members are working earnestly to

meets. Twenty.men have reported

leads them all in fancy diving.

CHESS CLUB HOLDS TOURNAMENT; SAIONTZ IS LEADING

The tournament being staged by
members of the Chess Club is progressing slowly but surely. In the
few games float have been played
R. L. Saiontz is leading, having
won all his matches so far. At the
end of the tournament, a chess
team (or possibly several teams)
will be formed of the best players.
Those competing in the tournament are: Kurrelmeyer, Shaw,
R. L. Saiontz, Douglas, Essers,
Parker, Feder, Yursick, Bowen,
Cohen, C. B. Saiontz, Hettleman,
Zubin, Feldman, Shortess, Hoen,
Mallalien, Taylor, Falkoff, M. Levin, P. Levin, Schiavo, Latane, Kabinofsky, Cromwell, B. S. Levin
and Rosenthal.
Mr. Spargo to Address Social
Science Club.

Mr. John Spargo, a prominent
American Socialist, is to address
the January -meeting of the Hopkins Social Science Club. Mr.
Spargo was prominent as a leader
in the American Socialist Party
until that party came out against
the war. Mr. Spargo and others
that supported the war resigned.
from the party after submitting a
minority report. In his book on
"Bolshevism," Mr. Spargo attacks
it as a form of autocracy and not
socialism. The subject and exact
date of Mr. Spargo's lecture will
be announced later. The next
meeting of the club will be held at
4 o'clock on Friday, December 19,
and will be addressed by ex-Judge
Alfred S. Niles.

Unless college professors receive
increased salaries soon "the last
college professor will die of malnutrition in'November, 1926," predicts Eliot Wadsworth, chairman

of the collegii professorianus will
then doubtless be placed along
with the dodo, the five-cent fare
and the gin rickey in the Smithsonian Intitution."

become associated to appeal to the
state for $5,000,000 during the
week of November 12-19 to solve
this problem of inadequate salaries for teachers and to meet other
immediate, pressing needs.

Too much Turkish
or

Just enough Turkish?
N one way, at least, smoking is
exactly like eating.
The more rich and delicious a
certain food is, the more care people
take to avoid eating too much of
it— for instance, plum pudding or
candy.

I

Perhaps this is the main reason
why so many smokers of straight
Turkish cigarettes keep switching
to Fatimas.

Less worry about
''too many"

Th3 Sam:" rule applies to smoking.
Cigar smokers, for example, are
today more careful to avoid too
many rich, heavy Havanas. (In fact,
mor3 and more cigar smokers now
smoke cigarettes too, to help cut
down the number of cigars.)
In th3 same way,cigarette smokers
are learning that Turkish tobacco,
delicious as it is, is so over-rich or
heavy, that a man can easily smoke
too much of it.
But they are learning also that,
instead of cutting down the number
of cigarettes per day, they can cut
down on the propoKion of Turkish
in each cigaret:c.

How to reduce on
Turkish
THEYcan dothis byswitching from
1- straight Turkish to part Turkish,
or "Turkish blend," cigarettes.
The first Turkish blend cigarette
ever made —and the one which has
always held first-rank importance—
is Fatima.
Fatima contains more Turkish
than does any other Turkish blend
cigarette.

ANOTHER reason undoubtedly is
11-• the fact that Fatimas treat
smokers so kindly. The Turkish is
so perfectly "balanced" by the other
tobaccos in the blend that Fatima
smokers never have any worry about
smoking "too many."
*

*

*

AT any rate, whatever the reason
may be,Fatima keeps on attracting more and more cf those smokers
who, if they preferred the fancy,
expensive, straight Turkish cigarettes, could easily afford them.
This is shown, of course, by
Fatima's record in having won the
top notch in sales at so many of the
fashionable clubs and hotels and
other prominent places all over the
country.

How much
is "just enough"?
not Fatima's record scem to
DOES
prove that this is the one cigarette containing just enough Turkish?
Not too much nor too little Turkish,
but just enough. Make a test for
yourself.

Perhaps to the students whose
homes are in Baltimore this lack
of gymnasium work at the University can be easily made up for by
exercise taken in their own yards
or houses. But we luckless inhabitants of nearby boardinghouses have no such opportunity.
We are, indeed, at a double disadvantage, because not only do
we lack facilities for physical
training, but, in addition, our systems must also suffer the continual abuse of boarding-house
menus, all of wliich are apparently planned to please the palate—
not the digestive apparatus.
The class which I hope may be
estdblished need not, I should
think, meet more than two days a
week. In my opinion, membership
in this class should be obligatory
among the freshmen and sophomores, for the military training
course at Hopkins is by no means
a satisfactory substitute for physical training. Many other universities require two years of both
military and gymnasium work,
hence it would not be imposing a
severe hardship on students to require them to take physical training in addition to the R. O. T. C.
course. Members of athletic teams,
of course, would be excused from
this proposed class.
The matter 'of good health as
fostered by proper bodily exercise
is clearly of great importance to
students. Real.work can be done
consistently only by students
whose systems are toughened by
regular bodily exercise. Hopkins
men should .not be characterized
by sallow complexious and flabby
muscles. '
N. M.
Attacks "Innocent Sufferer."
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—In your issue of last week
a letter appeared in the Mail Bag
in reference to the R. 0. T. C.
shoes and signed "Innocent Sufferer." "Innocent Sufferer" inferred that he could not study,
that his brain refused to work
whenever an R. 0. T. C. man shuffled his feet. It seems to me that
if the poor sufferer's brain had
only been of a kind that.produces
thought, he might have benefited
himself by observing the army
shoe. If he himself wore shoes of
army type his pedal extremities
would profit immensely in spite
of the noise.
Moreover, if this same "Innocent -Sufferer" had any college
spirit at all, even in most rudimentary form, it seems to me he
would either now be a member of
the organization which he so sarcastically criticizes or he would
keep his ridicule within his own
misguided mind. If such creatures
cannot boost a college activity, at
least they can and should refrain
from knocking it.
AN ANTI-"INNOCENT SUFFERER."
